prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 cont. + CO, 13CO, C18O (all J=2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: In this SG, we plan to take the ubiquitous gas line from a disk, 12CO, 13CO, and C18O (all J=2-1) as well as to detect dust continuum emission with 10-sigma detection. AA Ori has a large gap (~60AU) in the disk. The gap will be resolved with the desired angular resolution (0.14" => 60 AU at d=400pc).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The representative spectral window is baseband-2 (232GHz) configured for the continuum emission. The spectral window resolution for the lines of interest is about 0.2 km/s and the spectral window width is about 120 km/s. Therefore, the line is able to be resolved.
The correlation configuration for the lines of interest: 12CO (2-1), 13CO (2-1), and C18O (2-1). BB1 (baseband-1), BB2, and BB3 are configured to observe the lines of interest with the velocity resolution of ~0.16 km/s for 12CO (2-1) and 13CO (2-1) and ~0.33 km/s for C18O (2-1). The reason to increase the velocity resolution by spectral averaging for C18O is to increase the detection possibility of C18O because the flux density of C18O is usually fainter than 12CO and 13CO because it is optically thiner than other.
We set the bandwidth to wider than the line width to get the line-free region contributing to the underlying continuum.

We choose the desired angular resolution as 0.14". The desired angular resolution meet our need to resolve the gap (60AU) in the limit of standard mode.
We request LAS of 3" because gaseous disks can be extened by few thousand AU scale which is larger than the dusty continuum.

Our major interest in this ScienceGoal (SG) is to resolve the gap of AA Ori in contiuum distribution. Therefore, the sensitivity requirement for this Science Goal (SG) is based on the contiuum flux. We have measuered the continuum flux at 230 GHz with SMA, which was unable to resolve the radial structure), and the flux density is 19 mJy. Based on this measurement, we estimated the continuum flux density with the requested angular resolution (0.14") with the assumption of 100 AU disk size. It gives us 6 mJy for the peak continuum density. By checking the requested time and perforamce, we found that the slight increment of S/N doesn't effect much on the requested time (only few minute of total time (on-source and calibration time)), so we plan to achieve S/N~20. With this good S/N ratio, we can analyize the continuum distribution at band 6 with less confusion. This will also increase the possibility to detect the additional gas lines we aim to get for free along the continuum emission.
In this SG at band 6, the lines of interest are 12CO, 13CO, and C18O at J=2-1 transtion. These lines are basic probe to trace gas distribution of disks. Usually 12CO is the brightest and C18O is weakest among them. To estimate the peak line flux for this band, we choose the estimated line flux of 13CO, because (1) 13CO is optically thinner than 12CO and can trace more inner part of the disk than 12CO which are mostly trace disk surface and (2) 13CO is usually brighter than C18O. Under the assumption of that AA Ori is similar to T Tauri stars in Taurus, we adopted the average values peak flux density of 13CO (2-1) of DM Tau, GG Tau, and LkCa 15 as a reference value, then we estimated the expected peak flux density considering the distance of Orion and the desired angular resolution.
AA Ori has a massive disk, and we expect the gas abundance is large and we can detect 12CO, 13CO, and C18O to analyze the disk kinematics.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 cont, 12CO, HCO+, HCN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this SG, we focuse on the 12CO(3-2), and HCO+/HCN (4-3) transitions.
An additional baseband is configured to sample continuum, to constrain dust temperature.
We use this SG with band 3 or 6 SGs to more completely sample the CO, HCO+ HCN J-transition ladder, and signifiantly constrain radiative transfer analysis.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The representative baseband is baseband 2 (344.7 GHz) which is configured for continuum. The spectral window resolution for the spectral lines is about 0.2 km/s. Therefore, the lines can be resolved.
The correlation configuration for the lines of interst: 12CO (3-2), HCO+(4-3), HCN (4-3). BB1 for 12CO (3-2), BB3 for HCN (4-3) and HCO+ (4-3). The peak line flux is taken from the expected line flux density of HCO+. Based on the literatures of the observation of HCN (4-3) from T Tauri disks, the flux density of HCN (4-3) is usually similar to or slightly lower than HCO+ (4-3). Since HCO+(4-3) is expected to be detected at 4-sigma level, HCN (4-3) may be detected with the current correlation setup. We set 0.2km/s for the velocity resolution to detect kinematics structure of the dense part of the disk.

We choose the desired angular resolution as 0.1". It is the smallest angular resolution we can get without taking too much telescope time by setting the baseline greater than 2 km. With the angular resolution will resolve greater than 40 AU, then we can resolve the gap of AA Ori. If we set the same angular resolution applied for SG1 (0.14"), the requested time is only reduced by 2 min. To resolve the radial structure better, we take an advantage of smaller angular resolution in band 7 than that in band 6.
We request 3" for LAS because gaseous disks can be extended to few thousand AU scale which is larger than the dusty disk of few hundreds AU.

Similar to the SG at band 6, our major goal in thie SG is to resolve the gap of AA Ori in the fineast angular resolution requested in this proposal. Therefore, the sensitivity requirement for this SG is based on the continuum flux. We have measured the continuum flux at 350 GHz with SCUBA2 at JCMT, which is about 55mJy. Based on this measurement, we estimated the continuum flux density with the requested angular resolution (0.1") and a disk size of 100 AU. It gives us about 7 mJy for the peak continuum density.
In addition to the continuum emission, we also want to detect some dense tracers in band 7, 12CO (3-2), HCO+(4-3), and HCN (4-3), to constraint radiative transfer analysis with other gas lines in other bands. The peak line flux density is derived from the expected flux density of HCO+(4-3). The choice of HCO+ for a peak flux density of the line in this SG is because HCO+ often observed in disks with strong emission line. To estimate the expected peak flux density, we adopted average flux density of HCO+(4-3) from DM Tau, GM Aur, and RY Tau, then we scaled the flux density considering the distance of ONC (~400pc) and the angular resolution.
We request 0.2 mJy for RMS of the representative sideband which is set for continuum. We selected the RMS to comprimise the requested observation time and S/N of line and S/N of continuum. The S/N is greater than 20 for the expected continuum emission, and we also can detect the moleculare line with 4-sigma detection.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 cont. + 90 GHz gas tracers
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this SG, we plan to take typical dense-gas tracers in the 90 GHz range. Specifically HCN, HNC, HCO+ (all J=1-0). The relative strengths of one to the other will be applied to constraint disk model to determin gas and chemical abundances in AA Ori.
In addition, we also want to take the denisty tracers CH3OH (101.293).
The fourth baseband is configured to sample continuum, to constrain dust temperature.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The representative baseband is baseband-4 which is configured for continuum. The spectral window resolution for the spectral lines is about 2.0 km/s. Therefore, the lines can be resolved.
Justification for the spectral window setup for the line of interests: HCO+ (1-0), HCN (1-0), HNC (1-0), and CH3OH 7(-2,6)-7(1,6). BB1: HCO+ (1-0), HCN (1-0)much. BB2: HNC (1-0) BB3: CH3OH
For BB1 and BB2, the velocity resolution is 0.2~0.24 km/s. We set spectral averaging of 4 for BB1 to increase the detectibility of lines beause it dosen't loose velocity resolution

0.3" is our desired angular resolution for this SG. We do not aim to resolve the radial structure at band 3, but our goal in this SG is to get the photometry in the representative wavelength and get the dense tracer molecular emission lines to start constrain radiative transfer model for AA Ori. The synthesized beam size with the desired angular resolution will be similar to the size of dusty disk.
We request 3" for LAS because gaseous disks can be extended to few thousand AU scale which is larger than the dusty disk of few hundreds AU.

For this SG with the band 3, we use the baseband configured for continuum as a representative baseband. Because AA Ori has not been observed at 3.1 mm, we estimate the peak flux density with alpha = 2.5, the spectral index measured between 350GHz and 230GHz, by extrapolatig the flux density. The estimated flux density at band 3 is about 2 mJy. We do not aim to resolve the radial strucutre of the disk because we set the angular resolution with 0.3" which will be about 100 AU at the distance of ONC. Therefore we adopt 2 mJy as a peak flux density.
We also configure other basebands for HCN, HNC, HCO+, and CH3OH lines in this SG. The peak line flux is estimated from HCO+. As a reference value for the flux density estimation, we adopt the peak flux density of HCO+ of DM Tau, then we scaled it considering the distance of AA Ori. It gives 67 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 CN + cont.
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this SG, we visit Band 3 again. In this SG, we focus on taking CN emission lines. Within the two basebands configured for CN (1-0) will contain several emissions due to hyperfine structure of CN. We also use the remaining two basebands for continuum emission to enhance S/N of contiumm.
We devote this SG for CN because CN is typically stronger than HCN and HCO+. CN will be used to constrain disk model and temperature and density structure of AA Ori with HCO+ and HCN. Their line strenght relative to one another will offer important clues to determin disk's gas, density, settling structures.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our main interest in this SG is CN (1-0) hyperfine lines. Our choice of the representative window is CN line at 113.1162 GHz. We set the spectral window and the spectral resolution to make 3-sigma detection. At the representative baseband (baseband 1), we set three spectral windows for the hyperfine line emission both side to the representative spectral window. At baseband 2, we set a wide spectral window so that the hyperfine emission lines in both side from the center line at 113.5 Ghz can be included in the spectral window. We controled the spectral averaging values to meet 3-sigma detection as well as setting the similar spectral angular resolution of that in spectral windows at the basedband-1. Baseband 3 and 4 are for continuum emission.

0.3" is our desired angular resolution for this SG. We do not aim to resolve the radial dusty continuum structure at band 3 as explained in SG3, but our goal in this SG is to get CN emission lines with underlying continuum emission. The synthesized beam size with the desired angular resolution will be similar to the size of dusty disk.
We request 3" for LAS because gaseous disks may be extended to few thousand AU scale which is larget than the dusty disk of few hundred AU.

The representative baseband for this SG is baseband-1 configured for CN (113.14GHz) line. Our main focus of this SG is to take CN emission lines. We set RMS to detect CN emission lines with S/N~3. Our sensitivity request compromises with the 3-sigma detection of CN line and 30 min of observing time for this SG.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe AA Ori which is a pre-transitional disk having a radial gap of 60 AU. We propose to investigate AA Ori in ALMA bands 3, 6, and 7 with continuum emission and gas tracers, to get clues on the evolution of protoplanetary disk and planet formation/migration. AA Ori is located in Orion Nebular Cluster (age ~ 1 Myr) . We request the anglular resolution of 0.14" and 0.1"for band 6 and 7 to resolve the disk's radial strucutre. We do not resolve the disk's continuum structure at band 3. The molecular emission lines of interest are 12CO (2-1), 13CO (2-1), C18O (2-1), 12CO (3-2), HCO+ (4-3), HCN (4-3), HCN (1-0), HNC (1-0), HCO+(1-0), CH3OH, and CN. We will use channel maps of the molecular tracers and the underlying continuum to investigate disk properties of AA Ori as well as comparing the ratios of one line to other and continuum to constraint the radiative transfer analysis. The ALMA observation of AA Ori may work as a bridge from the gap openning in Class0/I disk(e.g. HL Tau) to the evolved disks in nearer star-forming regions, because it lies in between the cases. This observation will be the first observation of Transitional Disks around low-mass star in Orion A.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute
